text: The snow outside the north gate has been trampled to a shine. Soldiers run back and forth, orders ringing out one after another.
At the edge of the crowd, I spot Alicia. She’s issuing deployment instructions to several guards—fast, precise gestures, like she’s done this too many times before.
“Alicia!”
She glances back at me, her brow barely shifting.
“Go back to the inn.”
“I just wanted to make sure you—”
“If you stay here, you’ll distract Lucia. You’ll distract the guards.”
“I need them to finish what they’re supposed to do.”
“What about you?”
“I’ll hold this line.”
“Turn around now. Don’t make me waste time persuading you.”
She turns back immediately, continuing to issue commands—as if I’m just another nuisance to clear from the edge of the battlefield.
I grit my teeth but step back anyway. Not because I’m obedient—but because I suddenly understand: if I take one more step forward, she’ll have to divide her focus for me.
On the way back, the town feels like an invisible hand is gripping its throat.
Merchants pack up. Windows slam shut. Guards seal off intersections and hurry people indoors. Some try to ask about the north gate—no one answers fully.
As I walk, I hear people whisper her name, then quickly swallow it—as if finishing the sentence would make the ending real.
I return to the inn, slide the bolt into place, and brace a table against the door.
The fire burns brightly, yet the room feels like something is missing. The cups are lined up neatly on the counter, but no matter how much I wipe, it never feels like ‘today is over.’
I force myself to move: add firewood, tighten the bolts, place my short sword within easy reach. I finish once, then repeat it.
Later in the night, sounds drift from the north through the fog—a dull tremor, like distant walls collapsing. Then comes a long silence, so deep I can hear my own heartbeat.
I stand behind the counter, palm pressed flat against the wood, knuckles pale with strain.
Near the latter half of the night, footsteps finally pass outside. Quick. Heavy with snow and exhaustion. Someone murmurs in a lowered voice:
“North gate held.”
“Did everyone make it back?”
“Don’t ask… just go home.”
I don’t open the door. I don’t chase after them. I simply rest my forehead against the wood, my breathing growing heavier.
They never say her name—but I can tell: some came back. Some didn’t.
I sit behind the counter, eyes open until the sky turns pale. That night, I don’t sleep even once.
